episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. This motor vehicle accident case arose in Kentucky and involves Debra Marshall, with intake information provided by her boyfriend, Robert Grant. The caller, speaking English, identified Debra Marshall as the client and provided contact details for themselves: Robert Grant, phone numbers (270) 612-0090 and (270) 773-2138, caller ID 2706120090, best reachable times in the morning or early evening. Debra’s address is 1224 N Dixie Apt 1, Cave City, KY 42127, and her date of birth is 02/21/1956. Debra is not represented by an attorney at intake.

Incident details: The incident occurred in Kentucky on December 3, 2022. The incident time is recorded as 6:30 PM, with an alternate timestamp in the intake note of 12/3/2022 5:00:00 AM. The location was 1224 North Dixie Hwy, Cave City, KY, in rainy and wet weather. Debra was driving a 49cc moped and was the driver of her vehicle. She was turning left onto the street when she observed a vehicle far behind traveling at a high rate of speed; she skid for approximately 200 feet. A witness also reported that she was on the phone at the time. Two vehicles were involved. Police and EMS responded to the scene, and EMS transported Debra to a hospital. The other driver had auto insurance, while Debra’s vehicle did not have insurance coverage. The defendant’s vehicle make and model are not specified. The fault determination is unclear, though notes indicate Debra was “Most likely at fault.”

Injury and medical details: Debra sustained multiple injuries, including a subdural hematoma, 10 stitches in her right leg, a fractured/cracked right hip, a broken toe on her right foot, and numerous bruises. She was life-flighted to Nashville the same night. She received medical attention at TriStar Skyline Medical Center on 12/3/2022 and is currently being treated by Dr. Williams R T MD.

Vehicle and damage information: Debra’s vehicle is described as a 49cc moped. It sustained damage to the front, back, driver’s side, and passenger side. The other vehicle’s damage was noted as a front damage. At the time of the accident, Debra was not employed.

Insurance and case status: The other driver had insurance; Debra’s own vehicle did not have insurance. The claim numbers are not fully provided; BI (bodily injury) claim number is unsure, with BI claim status listed as Pending. The case type remains Motor Vehicle Accident, with fault factors listed as unsure who is at fault. The incident location is the same as stated above (1224 North Dixie Hwy, Cave City, KY), in the County of Accident listed as Barren. The client reports injury and ongoing medical treatment.

Intake and representation notes: The intake was conducted by Brandon French, with the Attorney of record listed as Aaron Whaley. The intake notes indicate that Debra was not represented at the time of intake. A note from 12/30/2022 at 6:18:08 PM shows that Brandon French changed the lead status to Signed Up and that a retainer had been signed, with the rest of the intake documents still needed.

Witness information: A witness named Carol provided information about the incident; her contact number is 1-270-599-7667.

Additional details: The case notes include a separate line item documenting the incident and the circumstances described above, including that Debra was turning left, observed a vehicle far back traveling at a high rate of speed, and skidded for about 200 feet, with a witness corroborating that Debra was on the phone. The incident is documented as having occurred within six months of today’s date, and the overall notes indicate the event involved two vehicles and a life-saving transport to Nashville.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall.

The notes chronicle Debra Marshall’s auto collision case and the surrounding firm communications. The file begins with an urgent follow-up thread in January 2023. On January 17, 2023, Aaron Whaley from Whaley Law Firm sent a forward titled “Debra Marshall | Urgent Follow Up Requested.” In that message, he asked that the firm reach out to Debra and instructed Debra not to communicate with the other driver’s insurance company. He noted that the other insurer had assigned fault to Debra, but he did not believe the fault was 100% on Debra and said he would handle matters with Kentucky Farm Bureau (KFB).

That same day, the message was a forward of a prior email from Farrokh Mokhtar, who was the Client Services Manager at LHP Law Group, PLLC. Mokhtar wrote that Debra had contacted them after receiving paperwork from the other driver's insurance company. He requested that Whaley’s team follow up with the insurer and also asked them to obtain the insurer’s office number for Debra. Mokhtar attached signed documents to his response. He signaled that the documents were part of the client’s intake and that a cooperative follow-up was needed. In his signature block, he identified himself and provided his contact information: Farrokh Mokhtar, Client Services Manager, LHP Law Group, PLLC, 805-509-2504 (cell), farrokhm@lhplawgroup.com.

This January 17 thread sits atop a longer December 2022–January 2023 communication trail about Debra Marshall’s potential representation and the administrative steps involved in onboarding her case. Several earlier exchanges document notary coordination and firm onboarding. For example, on December 29–30, 2022, there was a sequence in which Debra Marshall was being integrated as a client for notary services.

- On December 29, 2022, a chain of internal and client-facing messages discussed whether Debra Marshall would be entered as a client with LHP Law Group, and whether to submit documents under LHP. A note indicated that the Express Notary Service did not have Whaley on file as a client at that time. The Express Notary representative, Luke Vafiades, replied that they did not have Whaley on file and reminded recipients about the confidential nature of the email and its attachments.

- Earlier that same day, there were communications between Jay Rodriguez (and others at Whaley Law Firm) and Farrokh Mokhtar about who would sign and how to proceed. Jay Rodriguez confirmed that Debra Marshall had agreed to a Notary appointment for tomorrow, December 30, at 10:30 a.m., confirming the address as 1224 N Dixie Hwy, Apt 1, Cave City, KY 42127, with the contact phone number (270) 612-0090. The retainer was attached to this email. The exchange also communicated the client’s English language preference.

- A message from Farrokh Mokhtar at 12:13 PM on December 30 indicated that Debra Marshall had signed with a notary that morning and that the firm would welcome her to the practice once they received the documents. Mokhtar stated he would send over the documents as soon as they were received.

- On December 29, 2022, at 2:50 PM, an alert from the Alert Call Center noted: “WHALEY POTENTIAL CLIENT – AUTO ACCIDENT (FURTHER REVIEW NEEDED).” The note left the reason for further review as partially obscured (marked “Unsure wh…” in the forwarded snippet), reflecting an initial status of uncertainty about this being Whaley’s client and about how to file the matter.

- Also on December 29, 2022, at 2:59 PM, Express Notary asked: “Hi, are we entering this as a LHP signing?” In a prior thread at 2:00 PM that day, Aaron Whaley replied, “No, Whaley Law firm.” Earlier, at 1:46 PM, Jay Rodriguez had stated that Debra Marshall had agreed to a notary appointment for 12/30 and provided the client’s details (first name Debra, last name Marshall, language English, telephone number, and address). The notary appointment details, along with the statement that the retainer had been attached, were reiterated.

- Finally, at 3:02 PM on December 29, 2022, an email from a Whaley-affiliated note asked to “submit under LHP and use the doc Jay sent over,” indicating a procedural step to route Debra’s matter through LHP Law Group’s intake and notary process, rather than the Whaley firm directly.

Taken together, these notes show that Debra Marshall’s MVA case, initially arising in early December 2022, progressed through notary onboarding and intake coordination between Whaley Law Firm and LHP Law Group, with the latter coordinating signings and the transfer of documents. By late December, Debra had agreed to a notary appointment for December 30, 2022, at 10:30 a.m. at the Cave City address provided, and the retainer was attached to the correspondence. Express Notary was involved in the process, with some questions about whether the engagement would be filed under LHP or Whaley, and a request that a notary signature be obtained and documents be exchanged.

By mid-January 2023, the emphasis shifted to urgent client outreach and insurance communications. Debra had reportedly received paperwork from the other driver's (OD’s) insurance company, prompting Farrokh Mokhtar and the LHP team to request that Whaley’s team contact the client and coordinate follow-up with the insurer, including obtaining the insurer’s office number for Debra. The January 17 communication also notes that Farrokh had attached signed documents to his reply and reiterates the plan to handle the matter with KFB, while the Whaley team prepared to engage with Debra directly and advise her to refrain from communicating with the other insurer.

In summary: Debra Marshall’s case is the Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022 file. The organizational history includes onboarding activities with LHP Law Group in December 2022, notary appointment scheduling and completion around December 29–30, 2022, and an urgent follow-up thread in January 2023 in which Whaley urged direct client contact and cautioned against contacting the other insurer, with LHP coordinating follow-up and providing signed documents to support engagement. The January 17, 2023, exchange also indicates that Debra had received paperwork from the OD’s insurer and that the team would address fault considerations (noting that Debra’s fault was not believed to be 100% hers) and would handle matters with KFB.

Client: Debra Marshall

I spoke with a Mr Robert Grant who was there with Ms Marshall - gave him the office number and told him that Ms Marshall's case manager is JC. Client has pictures of injuries/accident - but said he is not very tech savvy - Ms Marshall was taken by "life flight" to Nashville Medical Center. She has had several MRI's and CAT Scans. episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on December 3, 2022 with Debra Marshall regarding a motor vehicle accident. I spoke with Mr. Robert Grant, who was with Ms. Marshall, and I gave him our office number while informing him that Ms. Marshall’s case manager is JC. The client has pictures documenting the injuries and the accident, though Mr. Grant said he is not very tech-savvy.

Ms. Marshall was life-flighted to Nashville Medical Center. She has had several MRI scans and CT (CAT) scans and suffered a hematoma and a concussion. I told Mr. Grant that his case manager would reach out to him for more detail, and I provided our office number. She still has walking difficulties and dizzy spells, having seen her PCP last week. She sustained multiple injuries, including a concussion and hematoma, and is still using a walker. #cc

When asked whether she had been referred for additional treatment, she said no. We advised Debra that we have not yet received her med auth; she stated that she had already sent it back. I informed her that a new med auth would be issued and asked her to notify us once she receives it.

Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. This note documents correspondence about Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident case, including a complaint draft and related communications.

On September 27, 2023, at 11:04:59 AM Eastern Time, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) sent an email to Bryce Koon (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com) and Debra Marshall (debramarshallz3106052@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com), with Sarena Tuttle cc’d, regarding Debra Marshall's complaint draft. In the message, Whaley wrote, “Yes, it’s a good one to file. I saved the location from the police report to the case summary. If you look at where it happened you can see that she made it a little way down the street before getting hit. Get open records for dash cam or body cam. Would love to see video of scene.”

Earlier that same day, Bryce Koon had responded around 10:39 AM, asking, “BI denied liability here? seems like it could have some teeth but not totally sure,” and noting that the complaint draft was attached for review. Aaron Whaley’s subsequent message reaffirmed the plan to move forward with filing and provided the observations described above, including the requested open records for dash cam or body cam footage and the desire to review video of the scene. Whaley signed the email as:

Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. This note summarizes the email chain from September 27, 2023, concerning Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident case (MVA) with a December 3, 2022 incident date, and the preparation of a complaint draft.

On September 27, 2023, at 11:26:24 a.m. Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Aaron Whaley (and with Bryce Koon and Debra Marshall CC’d) asking whether she should proceed to send an Open Records Request for dash-cam footage or similar camera footage. Sarena’s message preceded the firm’s internal discussion about next steps and the potential inspection of video from the scene. Her signature notes her role and includes her contact information and a new email address.

Earlier in the thread, Bryce Koon had sent a message around 10:39 a.m. noting that Bodily Injury (BI) liability had been denied and commenting that the case “seems like it could have some teeth but not totally sure.” Bryce added that the complaint draft was attached for review.

In the subsequent reply at approximately 11:04 a.m., Aaron Whaley replied that the case was a good one to file, indicating that he had saved the accident location from the police report to the case summary. He explained that a quick look at the location could show that Debra had progressed a short distance down the street before being struck. He advised obtaining open records for dash-cam or body-cam footage and expressed an interest in seeing video of the scene.

A follow-up reply around 11:07 a.m. from Aaron stated, “Don’t file yet. I want to get a demand out. If this is a minimum policy then they may just tender. It’s worth a few conversations with the adjuster.” This indicated a strategy to pursue a settlement demand before filing, depending on the policy limits and potential tender by the insurer.

The thread thus reflects a plan to file a complaint draft (with Bryce noting BI’s denial of liability and indicating the draft was attached for review), alongside consideration of obtaining open records for dash-cam or body-cam footage to illuminate the scene. The discussion also shows a strategy to first present a demand, particularly if the policy is not generous, before pursuing formal filing. Debra Marshall is the client, and her email address is included in the CC line along with the other participants. The firm’s contact details appear in the signatures, and Sarena notes a new email address.

The message was sent by Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm to Sarena Tuttle, with cc to Bryce Koon and Debra Marshall.

The body of Aaron’s initial email simply contained the word “yes.” In a preceding thread, Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, asked whether she should proceed with sending an Open Records Request (ORR) for camera footage, specifically dash cam or body cam video, to obtain footage of the scene. She also noted her new email address.

Earlier messages in the thread show Aaron advising: Do not file yet; he wants to issue a demand first, noting that if the at-fault policy is minimum, the insurer may tender without further pressure, and suggesting a few conversations with the adjuster. In a subsequent message, Aaron indicated that it was a good case to file and that he had saved the crash location from the police report to the case summary. Bryce Koon, another member of The Whaley Law Firm, commented that Bodily Injury (BI) liability had been denied and stated, “denied liability here — seems like it could have some teeth but not totally sure.” Bryce also noted that the complaint draft had been attached for review.

Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. Re: Debra Marshall - Complaint Draft.

On September 27, 2023, in the Debra Marshall motor vehicle accident matter, an email thread was exchanged regarding the draft of Debra Marshall’s complaint. The message originated from Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and was sent to Aaron Whaley with Bryce Koon and Debra Marshall cc’d. The subject line read “Re: Debra Marshall - Complaint Draft.” The header information notes the date as September 27, 2023 at 11:36:55 AM, with a -0400 time zone.

In the body of the initial note, Sarena reports that she called Cave City Police Department to obtain ORR instructions. Per Chief Miller, the department does not use dash cams or body cameras. Sarena’s signature block follows, including her role and contact details and a note indicating her email address is the new one: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

The thread then shows a rapid back-and-forth. Around 11:27 AM, Aaron Whaley replied with a brief “yes.” Moments earlier, at approximately 11:26 AM, Sarena asked, “Should I go ahead and send ORR for cam footage?” followed by her signature block.

Earlier still, at about 11:07 AM, Aaron advised, “Don’t file yet. I want to get a demand out. If this is a minimum policy then they may just tender. It is worth a few conversations with the adjuster.” This comment followed an earlier exchange captured in the thread.

At approximately 10:39 AM, Bryce Koon contributed, noting, “BI denied liability here ? seems like it could have some teeth but not totally sure.” He also stated that the complaint draft was attached for review, and he signed as Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm, providing his contact details.

The thread contains multiple closing sign-offs from Aaron Whaley, all identifying him as with The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the firm’s phone number, 502-583-4022, repeated in the signature blocks. Debra Marshall is listed in CC on the thread, with an address associated to her Louisville incident law firm filevine app contact.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022 documents Debra Marshall as the client in a motor vehicle accident that occurred on December 3, 2022. The file includes a forwarded urgent follow-up from December 21, 2023, in which the sender states: “Please call Debra Marshall. Looks like she may have gotten a summons.” The forward is part of an email thread sent by Aaron Whaley to Bryce Koon, Sarena Tuttle, and Debra Marshall’s file link, with the subject Debra Marshall | Urgent Follow Up Requested and the timestamp Thursday, December 21, 2023 at 14:15:45 Eastern Time.

Within that 2023 forwarding, a prior message from Farrokh Mokhtar is summarized: “Mr. Grant needs to speak with Justin regarding a summons they received today. Could you please have someone reach out to him ASAP?” A phone number is provided: 270-308-6916. The message is addressed to Aaron Whaley and Brandon at Whaley Law Firm, with Mark Sullivan copied from LHP Law Group, and it is signed by Farrokh Mokhtar, Client Services Manager, LHP Law Group, PLLC (contact information included in the signature block).

The thread also contains a series of earlier communications dating back to 2023 and 2022. On January 17, 2023, Farrokh Mokhtar wrote to Aaron Whaley and others: “The client reached out to us because they received some paperwork from the OD’s insurance company. Could you please have your team follow up with them? Please also request them to provide the client with the office number.” Mokhtar noted that signed documents were attached to the response. On January 26, 2023, Mokhtar again stated that they were continuing to receive calls and that it appears the other party is attempting to send over some of the requested documents; he asked that their Case Manager reach out to the client and ensure a direct number was provided.

Turning to December 2022, the thread shows that on December 29, 2022, Jay Rodriguez advised that Debra Marshall had agreed to a notary appointment for tomorrow, December 30, at 10:30 AM, and he confirmed the address and time. He provided Debra’s basic client details: first name Debra, last name Marshall, language English, and telephone number (270)612-0090. He also listed the appointment address as 1224 N Dixie Hwy, Apt 1, Cave City, KY 42127, and he stated that the retainer had been attached to the email. Earlier that same day, a message from an Express Notary Service representative (Luke Vafiades) indicated that Whaley was not on file as a client, and asked whether this should be entered as a LHP signing. This exchange included the line: “We don’t have Whaley on file as a client as far as I can tell.” Another message, sent at 2:00 PM, clarified: “No, Whaley Law firm.” A subsequent note at 2:59 PM asked, “Hi, are we entering this as a LHP signing?” and later, at 3:02 PM, a reply from the legal team instructed to submit under LHP and to use the document Jay sent over.

In a follow-up to that same day, Jay Rodriguez replied at 1:46 PM that Debra Marshall had agreed to a notary appointment for tomorrow, confirmed her address and time, and noted that the retainer had been attached. The 3:02 PM messages from Farrokh Mokhtar reiterated the need to process the matter in the correct system (LHP) and to use the doc Jay had provided. By December 30, 2022 at 12:13 PM, Mokhtar reported that Debra and her party had signed with a notary that morning and requested that someone reach out to welcome them to the firm, with a promise to send over documents as soon as they were received. The thread also confirms the broader collaboration between the Whaley firm and LHP Law Group, PLLC, including the presence of Express Notary Service communications and the involvement of multiple staff members (Intake, Mark Rinehart, Mark Sullivan, Gigi Andueza, Diana Diaz, Elena Dunne, Sarah Peters, Kalli Erickson, and others) in facilitating the notary process and document handling.

In summary, the Debra Marshall case involves an MVA from December 3, 2022, with a multi-organization correspondence trail spanning December 2022 through January 2023, detailing notary arrangements, document handling, insurer paperwork, and client follow-up. A further urgent follow-up note from December 21, 2023 indicates Debra may have received a summons, and directs contact with Debra, including a separate note that Mr. Grant needs to speak with Justin regarding the summons, with Justin’s phone number listed as 270-308-6916. Debra Marshall’s contact details documented in the thread include a telephone number of (270) 612-0090 and an address at 1224 N Dixie Hwy, Apt 1, Cave City, KY 42127.

This note covers the Debra Marshall matter arising from Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident case, captioned as Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. The relevant filings and communications concern the district court action KFBMIC (a/s/0 Edie Renick) v. Debra Marshall, Barren District Court case number 23-C-01110, and the client is Debra Marshall.

On December 27, 2023, in an email to John Bertram, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, stated that all of Bertram’s presumptions were correct. Koon informed Bertram that they had filed a circuit court action against Jasmine Reed, who drove Ms. Renick’s vehicle, in Circuit Court. The circuit court case number is 23-CI-00659. Reed was served via certified mail on December 13, 2023, but no answer has been filed to date. Koon explained his intention to file a motion to consolidate the district court case into the circuit court case, and he asked Bertram to indicate any objections to the attached motion; if there were none, Koon would draft an agreed order. The message included Koon’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email also contained the standard privilege disclaimer stating the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information; recipients who are not intended to receive the message should notify The Whaley Law Firm, and should not use or forward the information.

Earlier, Bertram had replied on December 27, 2023, at 9:37 a.m. that he had been advised a separate matter had been filed in the Barren Circuit Court, presumably arising from the same facts, and that his understanding was that Koon’s firm initiated that action. Bertram asked Koon to confirm his understanding and, if correct, whether the matters should be consolidated. He noted a potential difference in damages (district court versus circuit court) but suggested judicial economy might support consolidation. Bertram also asked whether an answer had been filed in the matter Koon had initiated. Bertram’s signature included his contact details: John D. Bertram, (270) 789-3676. The CC list on the message included Sarena Tuttle, Allan R. Bertram, Debby Bennett, and Landon Cambron.

On December 26, 2023, at 2:05 p.m., Koon sent another message to Bertram with Allan R. Bertram copied, attaching documents that had been filed that day in Barren District Court and noting, “Please see attached filed today in Barren District Court.” The message again carried The Whaley Law Firm’s standard privilege disclaimer.

In the later message from December 27, 2023, at 10:01 a.m., Koon reiterated that all of Bertram’s presumptions were correct: a circuit court action against Jasmine Reed had been filed, case number 23-CI-00659, with Reed served by certified mail on December 13, 2023, and no answer filed to date. He confirmed his intention to file a motion to consolidate the district court case into the circuit court case and indicated that, if Bertram had no objections to the attached motion, he could draft an agreed order. The signature block again included Bryce Koon’s contact information for The Whaley Law Firm and the customary attorney-disclaimer language.

Overall, the communications reflect that a separate circuit court action was filed against Jasmine Reed related to the same facts, service of process on Reed occurred on December 13, 2023 with no answer yet, and there is an ongoing plan to consolidate the district court case 23-C-01110 into the circuit court action, with an attached motion on file and a potential agreed order to be drafted if there are no objections. The exchanges were between W. Bryce Koon, Esq., and John D. Bertram, with multiple cc recipients, and they include standard attorney-client privilege notices in the signature blocks.

episodes.natural_language:
Debra Marshall was involved in a motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022. In late December 2023, her case surfaced in two related filings arising from that incident. The Whaley Law Firm, on behalf of KFBMIC (Kentucky Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company) in a matter captioned KFBMIC (a/s/0 Edie Renick) v. Debra Marshall, filed a case in Barren District Court against Debra Marshall, assigned District Court case number 23-C-01110. This action is part of the Debra Marshall MVA case referenced as Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022.

On December 26, 2023, counsel for KFBMIC advised that a circuit court action had been filed against Jasmine Reed, driver of Edie Renick’s vehicle, in the Barren Circuit Court, with Case No. 23-CI-00659. Reed was served with the circuit court action via certified mail on December 13, 2023, and, at that time, no answer had been filed. The email indicated an intent to move to consolidate the district court case into the circuit court case, and that, if there were no objections, an agreed order could be drafted.

The next day, December 27, 2023, John D. Bertram inquired by email whether the firm would be defending in the circuit court matter and whether the matters should be consolidated, noting a likely difference in damages between district court and circuit court actions but citing judicial economy as a reason to consolidate. He also asked whether an answer had been filed in the matter initiated by KFBMIC.

Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm replied on December 27, 2023, confirming that the circuit court action had indeed been filed against Jasmine Reed, Case No. 23-CI-00659, and that Reed had been served by certified mail on December 13, 2023, with no answer having been filed to date. He stated his intention to file a motion to consolidate the district court case (23-C-01110) into the circuit court case (23-CI-00659) and offered to draft an agreed order if there were no objections.

Shortly thereafter, Bertram responded that he had been advised of the separate circuit court filing arising from the same facts and asked Koon to confirm whether his understanding was correct and whether the matters should be consolidated. He again noted the potential difference in damages between district and circuit court actions but suggested consolidation could serve judicial economy, and he asked whether an answer had been filed in the matter initiated by KFBMIC.

At 10:47 a.m. on December 27, 2023, a forwarded message from Bryce Koon circulated the preceding exchange. The forwarded content reiterates Bertram’s inquiry about consolidation and reflects KFBMIC’s stance that the district court case (23-C-01110) and the circuit court case (23-CI-00659) were being coordinated, with the possibility of an agreed order if there were no objections. The message also includes the standard confidentiality disclaimer typical of communications from The Whaley Law Firm and the sender’s contact information, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information; recipients receiving the message in error are instructed to notify The Whaley Law Firm, avoid waiving privileges, and not to disclose the content to others.

In summary, in December 2023, two related actions emerged from the same underlying facts: a district court case in Barren District Court against Debra Marshall (23-C-01110) and a circuit court case against Jasmine Reed (23-CI-00659). Reed was served on December 13, 2023, with no answer filed, and counsel discussed consolidating the district and circuit court matters, with the possibility of drafting an agreed order pending any objections.

On December 26, 2023, Bryce Koon sent an email to John Bertram with the subject RE: KFBMIC (a/s/o Edie Renick) v. Debra Marshall (Barren District Court 23-C-01110). Earlier in the thread, on December 27, 2023, John Bertram replied at 9:37 AM. He said he had been advised that a separate matter had been filed in Barren Circuit Court, apparently arising from the same facts, and he asked Bryce to confirm whether his understanding was correct and whether the matters should be consolidated. Bertram noted that he presumed there would be a difference in damages (district versus circuit court) but suggested that judicial economy might favor consolidation, and he asked whether an answer had been filed in the matter initiated by Bryce’s firm.

Bryce Koon responded at 10:02 AM the same day. He confirmed that Bertram’s presumptions were correct: a circuit court action had been filed against Jasmine Reed (the driver of the vehicle involved in Edie Renick’s claim), identified as Case No. 23-CI-00659. Reed was served via certified mail on December 13, 2023, but no answer had been filed to date. Koon stated his intention to file a motion to consolidate the district court case into the circuit court case and offered to draft an agreed order if Bertram had no objections to the attached motion.

Shortly after, at 10:23 AM on December 27, 2023, John Bertram replied again. He thanked Bryce and said he was not sure whether KFBMIC would be defending in the circuit court matter but had inquired. He indicated he would inform Bryce if there was any opposition to consolidation, though he could not imagine there would be.

The thread also shows an additional message from Bryce on December 27, 2023, to John Bertram (9:37 AM) and a follow-up at 9:37 AM from Bertram, indicating ongoing discussion about consolidation and the relative timing of the actions. Earlier, on December 26, 2023, Bryce had again referenced the attached filing in Barren District Court.

As with the prior messages, the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer appeared at the bottom of the email.

In summary, the file reflects Debra Marshall’s representation in the district court case 23-C-01110, with a parallel circuit court action against Jasmine Reed in Case No. 23-CI-00659. There were ongoing discussions about consolidating the district court case into the circuit court matter, including service on Jasmine Reed (via certified mail on 12/13/2023) and no answer filed to date, as of December 2023. - December 27, 2023, 10:23 a.m. (To: Bryce Koon; CC: Sarena Tuttle; Allan R. Bertram; Debby Bennett; Landon Cambron): John Bertram responded, Good morning. He said he had been advised that a separate matter had been filed in Barren Circuit Court, presumably arising from the same facts, and reiterated his understanding that Bryce’s firm initiated that action. He asked for confirmation and whether the matters should be consolidated. He noted a presumed difference in damages (district vs. circuit) but believed judicial economy might favor consolidation. He also asked whether an answer had been filed in the circuit matter.

- December 26–27, 2023: The emails reference an attached filing in Barren District Court (from Bryce’s December 26 message) and discuss the existence and status of a circuit court action against Jasmine Reed (Case No. 23-CI-00659) with service recorded on December 13, 2023 and no answer filed yet. The parties repeatedly considered filing a motion to consolidate the district and circuit court actions and whether an agreed order could be drafted.

- January 15, 2024, 2:34 p.m. (From: Bryce Koon; To: John Bertram; CC: Sarena Tuttle; Allan R. Bertram; Debby Bennett; Landon Cambron): Bryce wrote Good afternoon, John. He asked him to see the attached filing in Barren District Court, noting that it had been filed that day. He invited any questions.

- January 15, 2024, 7:41 p.m. (From: John D. Bertram; To: Bryce Koon; CC: Sarena Tuttle; Allan R. Bertram; Debby Bennett; Landon Cambron): John responded with simply “Thank you,” followed by his standard signature block including his phone number (270) 789-3676.

Other notable details
- The parties’ counsel and recipients were repeatedly cc’d: Sarena Tuttle, Allan R. Bertram, Debby Bennett, and Landon Cambron, with the primary correspondence between John D. Bertram (BCM LLP) and W. Bryce Koon (The Whaley Law Firm). The January 15, 2024 exchanges show the same group in the distribution.

- Attachments and formatting: In the January 15, 2024 emails, Bryce’s message referenced an attached filing in the Barren District Court (the message also included an image attachment noted as [cid:image001.png...]). The messages repeatedly stated they were confidential and attorney-client privileged, including standard notices about forwarding, privilege, and error handling.

- Case context and status: The note confirms the district court case, 23-C-01110, involves Debra Marshall as the defendant in a matter arising from a motor vehicle accident (Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022). The circuit court action referenced, against Jasmine Reed, is in Case No. 23-CI-00659, with service by certified mail on December 13, 2023 and no filed answer at the time of the communications. The parties discussed consolidating the district court case into the circuit court action to promote efficiency.

- The final entries (January 15, 2024) show a subsequent filing in the Barren District Court being communicated by Bryce to John, with John acknowledging receipt.

Overall, the note captures the procedural posture of late December 2023 through January 2024: a district court filing by The Whaley Law Firm related to KFBMIC, a parallel or separate circuit court action against Jasmine Reed, service on Reed without an answer, ongoing discussions about consolidating the district and circuit court proceedings, and a later January 15, 2024 filing in the district court followed by a brief acknowledgment from John Bertram. Confidentiality notices accompany the messages, and the communications include the usual attorney-contact details and distribution lists.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra Marshall MVA 12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall.

Initial client contact on January 22, 2024: Sarena received a voicemail from Robert Grant checking on the status of Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident case. In a returned call, the litigation was discussed. The Master Trial Conference (MTCon) is on the docket for January 23, 2024. It was explained that once the cases are consolidated, we will move into the Discovery Phase and will forward the DC Discovery Request as soon as they are received. Mr. Grant stated that he had heard via “the grapevine” that the officer on the scene and the defendant driver were/are romantically involved. He also claimed they are seeing “someone” who he believes to be a guy and a girl who assaulted the client at the scene, driving by their home and harassing them. He was advised to contact local police and file a report in case of escalation, though he does not feel comfortable doing so due to the suspected romantic relationship between the defendant and the officer. It was advised that AW and BK would be made aware of the situation. The person making contact was Sarena, and the date and time recorded were January 22, 2024.

The case is Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed in the Barren Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-00659, arising from Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022. The client in this matter is Debra Marshall.

On January 23, 2024, at 8:53 a.m., W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, sent an email to hrh@scrtc.com with Sarena Tuttle copied, regarding Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed (Barren Circuit 23-CI-00659). He noted that discovery requests had been served contemporaneously with the Complaint and asked for guidance on when responses might be provided, offering to supply the requests if needed and willing to grant an extension if necessary. He also informed that KFB, acting on Edie Renick’s behalf, had filed a property damage claim in Barren District Court against his client. He had filed a motion to consolidate that case with the above-styled case, which would be heard that day and would likely face no objection. He closed with thanks and provided his contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363. The message carried the standard electronic privilege disclaimer indicating it was intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information; if received in error, the recipient was instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and not to disclose or forward the contents.

Later that same day, January 26, 2024 at 12:45 p.m., Hensley & Ross responded to Bryce Koon. In their reply, Pat (Patrick) Hensley stated that he appreciated the agreement to grant additional time to respond to the discovery served with the complaint and requested another 30 days, which he believed would be sufficient. The message was sent from Hensley & Ross, Attorneys at Law, located at 207 E. Main St., P.O. Box 350, Horse Cave, KY 42749, with phone 270-786-2155 and fax 270-786-2118. The response included the same standard electronic privilege disclaimer.

Also on January 23, 2024, Bryce Koon had previously written again, in a separate message sent at 8:53 a.m. to hrh@scrtc.com with Sarena Tuttle CC’d, regarding the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed matter. He reminded Patrick that discovery requests were served with the Complaint and asked to be advised when responses might be expected; he reiterated willingness to provide the discovery documents or to request an extension if needed. He again referenced that KFB, on Edie Renick’s behalf, had filed a property damage claim in Barren District Court against his client and that he had filed a motion to consolidate that case with the current action, which would be heard today and would likely face no objection. He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the same Louisville address and contact details as above, and again included the standard electronic privilege disclaimer.

In summary, communications regarding Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed (Barren Circuit 23-CI-00659) between January 23 and January 26, 2024 documented discovery response timing concerns, a contemporaneous property damage claim filed against Debra Marshall in Barren District Court (and a motion to consolidate), and a mutual agreement to extend deadlines by 30 days, with corresponding attorney acknowledgments and boilerplate privilege notices attached to each message.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. This matter is Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed, filed in Barren Circuit Court under docket number 23-CI-00659.

On March 19, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, emailed counsel for the defense, Hensley & Ross, at hrh@scrtc.com with a copy to Debra Marshall’s file email DebraMarshallZ3106052@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The subject line reiterated the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed matter. In his message, Koon stated, Good afternoon counsel, I just wanted to get an update on the outstanding requests. He signed the email with his contact information—W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363—and included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer common to electronic communications: the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should notify The Whaley Law Firm and should not use or forward the information. The email was part of an ongoing discovery/dialogue in the case.

The email thread includes earlier communications beginning in January 2024. On January 23, 2024, Bryce Koon sent to Hensley & Ross at hrh@scrtc.com with Sarena Tuttle cc’d, reasserting that discovery requests had been served contemporaneously with the Complaint. He asked Hensley & Ross to advise when the office could expect responses, and offered to provide the discovery documents if needed or to arrange an extension if required. In that same message, Koon noted that KFB, acting on behalf of Edie Renick, had filed a property-damage claim in Barren District Court against his client. He stated that he had filed a motion to consolidate that case with the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed matter, which would be heard that day and would likely face no objection. He invited any questions about the consolidation and the related matters. The message ended with thanks and his signature block, including The Whaley Law Firm’s address and contact details, and it carried the standard privilege disclaimer.

On January 26, 2024, at 12:05 PM, Bryce Koon responded to Hensley & Ross with the subject Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed (Barren Circuit 23-CI-00659). He wrote that “30 days should be fine,” and again provided his contact information and the usual privilege disclaimer.

Later that same day, January 26, 2024, at 12:45 PM, Hensley & Ross replied to Bryce Koon. In the message, which began with “Bryce:,” they thanked him for agreeing to grant additional time to respond to the discovery served with the complaint and requested that he give them “another 30 days” if possible. The reply was signed by Pat from Hensley & Ross, Attorneys at Law, with the firm’s address at 207 E. Main St., P.O. Box 350, Horse Cave, KY 42749, and contact information: phone 270-786-2155, fax 270-786-2118. The message also contained the standard privilege disclaimer.

On January 29, 2024, at 12:26 PM, Hensley & Ross again emailed Bryce Koon in the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed matter. The body of that message consisted of a brief “Thanks,” and, as with the other emails, included the firm’s contact details and the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Across all messages in the thread, the subject consistently appeared as Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed (Barren Circuit 23-CI-00659). The communications reflect discovery timing concerns and the parties’ negotiations over extending deadlines for responses to discovery, as well as a contemporaneous notice of a related property-damage case and an attempted consolidation. The correspondence also shows ongoing attention to privilege protections in electronic communications.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Skyline Request - Need to Provide Updated ID - CPD ID in file is expired - Called Client - She unaware ID Expired - Can not update until 1st of the month - Also discuss the 'city' has been putting up new signs regarding the speed limits & other safety signs - Also her providers have found a 'black spot' on her eye that can only be caused by a 'hard fall' they are sending her for more testing on that issue - Advised client to get us posted if she goes to see an ophthalmologist or any other new provider - She expressed understanding & will get her ID updated asap 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: April 08 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on April 8, 2024 with Sarena regarding Debra Marshall's motor vehicle accident case Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. A Skyline Request was received indicating the CPD ID on file is expired and an updated ID is needed. I called the client; she was unaware that her ID had expired and was told that the update cannot be completed until the first of the month.

We also discussed that the city has been putting up new signs related to speed limits and other safety signage. Her providers have identified a black spot on her eye that can only be caused by a hard fall, and they are sending her for further testing on this issue. I advised the client to notify us if she sees an ophthalmologist or any other new provider. She expressed understanding and will update her ID as soon as possible.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. The matter is Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed in the Barren Circuit Court, docket 23-CI-00659. The following notes summarize the email communications between The Whaley Law Firm and the law firm Hensley & Ross regarding discovery responses, set in the context of Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident case against Jasmine Reed.

The exchange begins with an email dated January 23, 2024. W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (Louisville, Kentucky) wrote to Patrick Hensley of Hensley & Ross, with copies to Sarena Tuttle and Debra Marshall’s file-service address, explaining that discovery requests had been served contemporaneously with the Complaint and asking when the opposing side could be expected to provide responses. He offered to extend time if needed or to resend the discovery if necessary. Koon also noted that KFB (on behalf of Edie Renick) had filed a property damage claim in Barren District Court against his client, and that he had filed a motion to consolidate that case with the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed action, which was to be heard that day and would likely face no objection. He invited any questions and signed with his contact information and the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

On January 26, 2024, at 12:05 PM, Koon replied to Hensley & Ross with: “30 days should be fine.” He again provided his contact details. Later that same day, at 12:45 PM, Hensley & Ross replied: “Bryce: Thank you for agreeing to grant me additional time to respond to the discovery served with the complaint. If you could give me another 30 days that should be sufficient.” Pat of Hensley & Ross closed with their firm’s address and contact information, accompanied by the standard disclaimer about privileged information.

On January 29, 2024, Hensley & Ross sent a brief reply simply saying, “Thanks,” followed by the firm’s mailing address and contact details, again with the customary disclaimer.

The next sequence of correspondence occurred on March 19, 2024. At 10:39 AM, Bryce Koon sent an email to Hensley & Ross, addressed for counsel, cc’ing Debra Marshall’s file address, inquiring: “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to get an update on the outstanding requests.” He signed again as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the usual contact information and privilege disclaimer.

That same day, March 19, 2024, at 4:46 PM, Hensley & Ross replied: “Like always I am running behind. I will get in touch with her and get those answered within the near future.” The message carried the firm’s standard signature lines and disclaimer.

Finally, on April 9, 2024, at 1:48 PM (Eastern Time, -0400), Bryce Koon sent another message to counsel: “Good afternoon counsel, I am writing again to determine when we may expect your client’s discovery responses. It appears these requests have been outstanding for some time now.” He concluded with his signature block for The Whaley Law Firm, Louisville, KY, and the same standard privilege disclaimer.

Throughout these exchanges, the subject line consistently referenced Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed (Barren Circuit 23-CI-00659). The communications include the parties and counsel identified above, the case identity, the discovery timeline discussions, and the motion to consolidate a separate property damage claim filed in Barren District Court (KFB, on behalf of Edie Renick) with the Debra Marshall matter, all set against the backdrop of a motor vehicle accident occurring on December 3, 2022. Each email ends with the customary attorney-client privilege disclaimer and the sender’s contact information.

In the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed case (Barren Circuit Court, docket 23-CI-00659), arising from a motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022, the client is Debra Marshall. The Whaley Law Firm, represented by W. Bryce Koon, began a series of discovery communications with Hensley & Ross, whose contact is Patrick (Pat) Hensley, concerning the discovery responses tied to the case.

On January 23, 2024, Bryce Koon emailed Pat Hensley at Hensley & Ross, noting that discovery requests had been served contemporaneously with the complaint and asking for an update on when the office could expect responses. He offered to provide the discovery documents if needed and invited an extension of time or for him to resend the materials. Bryce also informed Hensley & Ross that KFB (a/s/o Edie Renick) had filed a property damage claim in Barren District Court against his client, and that he had filed a motion to consolidate that case with the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed case, which would be heard that day and would likely face no objection. He signaled willingness to accommodate any questions and provided his contact details.

Subsequently, on January 26, 2024, Bryce replied that 30 days would be fine. Pat Hensley responded later that day, thanking Bryce for agreeing to grant additional time to respond to the discovery served with the complaint and stating that another 30 days would be sufficient.

Also on January 26, 2024, Bryce sent another message in the same thread, and on January 29, 2024, Hensley & Ross replied with a brief “Thanks.”

On January 29, 2024, Bryce’s message had been sent from The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363), and the Hensley & Ross firm responded from their office (207 E. Main St., P.O. Box 350, Horse Cave, KY 42749; phone 270-786-2155; fax 270-786-2118). The email disclaimers in these communications indicated that the messages were intended for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information, with instructions to contact the sender if received in error and not to disclose the contents.

Fast forwarding to March 2024, Bryce again sought an update. On March 19, 2024, at 10:39 AM, Bryce emailed Hensley & Ross again, asking for an update on the outstanding discovery requests and indicating that the message had been CC’d to Debra Marshall’s file (DebraMarshallZ3106052@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com).

Later that same day, March 19, 2024 at 4:46 PM, Pat Hensley replied that he was running behind as usual but would contact Debra Marshall and arrange for the requested discovery to be answered in the near future.

Finally, on April 9, 2024, 1:48 PM, Bryce wrote again to counsel, asking when the client’s discovery responses could be expected, noting that the requests had been outstanding for some time. The message again carried the standard privilege disclaimer common to these communications.

These exchanges reflect a pattern of delayed discovery responses in the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed matter, with multiple extensions requested and granted, and ongoing efforts to coordinate related matters, including the consolidation of a separate property damage claim filed by KFB on Edie Renick’s behalf.

Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall.

In April 2024, a sequence of email communications occurred between Debra Marshall’s care provider and her legal representatives regarding the motor vehicle accident case. The exchange centers on the handling of Debra Marshall’s medical records and related billing. On April 11, 2024 at 11:59 AM, Sarena Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Tamara Shive with the subject “RE: D. Marshall.” The message included a caution that the email was from an external source and advised not to open attachments or click links from an unknown or suspicious origin, and it then asked, “Thank you so much. Will the billing come under separate cover?”

Tamara Shive replied later that day, at 3:31:51 PM, stating, “Per your written request, I have attached the medical records regarding Debra Marshall.” The email carried a [cid:image001.png@01DA8C0C.EFA89530] reference to an image and included the website link http://www.tjregionalhealth.org. It also contained a Privacy Notice informing that the information in the message (including all attachments) may be privileged and confidential and protected from disclosure. It warned that if the reader is not the intended recipient, or an employee or agent responsible for delivering the message to the intended recipient, any dissemination, distribution, or copying is strictly prohibited. If the communication was received in error, the recipient was instructed to notify the sender immediately and to delete or destroy the material and information. This Privacy Notice appeared twice in the email.

Additionally, the correspondence from Tamara Shive included her signature line and the organization’s website, http://www.tjregionalhealth.org. Finally, at 5:36:55 PM on the same day, Tamara Shive clarified in a separate note that, “Yes, billing will always arrive separately, as it is another department.”

episodes.natural_language:
Debra Marshall is the client in case Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022, a motor vehicle accident that occurred on December 3, 2022. 

The record shows that the defendant's response to the Request for Admission was received, and it places fault on Debra Marshall. The defendant contends that Debra Marshall pulled out in front of the defendant, who was operating a moped. The posted speed limit at the location was 55 mph, and the defendant asserts that he could not avoid the collision.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed, in the Barren Circuit Court (case number 23-CI-00659). The matter stems from a motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022, and the client is Debra Marshall. Debra Marshall is represented by The Whaley Law Firm, with W. Bryce Koon, Esq., handling the matter. The following is a narrative summary of the discovery-related correspondence between The Whaley Law Firm and Hensley & Ross, along with related context.

In late January 2024, The Whaley Law Firm began a series of communications regarding discovery. On January 23, 2024, Bryce Koon emailed Patrick Hensley of Hensley & Ross, noting that discovery requests had been served contemporaneously with the Complaint and asking when the responses could be expected. He offered to provide an extension if needed or to send the discovery requests himself. He also informed Hensley & Ross that KFB, acting for Edie Renick, had filed a property damage claim in Barren District Court against Debra Marshall. He indicated that he had filed a motion to consolidate that property damage case with the Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed matter, which would be heard that day and would likely face no objection. He invited any questions regarding these matters.

On January 26, 2024, at 12:05 PM, Bryce Koon replied that a 30-day extension would be fine. Later that day, at 12:45 PM, Hensley & Ross responded: “Bryce: Thank you for agreeing to grant me additional time to respond to the discovery served with the complaint. If you could give me another 30 days that should be sufficient.” On January 29, 2024, at 12:26 PM, Hensley & Ross sent a brief acknowledgment: “Thanks.”

Moving forward, on March 19, 2024, at 10:39 AM, Bryce Koon asked for an update on the outstanding discovery requests. That same day, at 4:46 PM, Hensley & Ross replied: “Like always I am running behind. I will get in touch with her and get those answered within the near future. Thanks.”

On April 9, 2024, at 12:48 PM, Bryce Koon wrote again, stating: “Good afternoon counsel, I am writing again to determine when we may expect your client’s discovery responses. It appears these requests have been outstanding for some time now.” Later that day, at 2:34 PM, Hensley & Ross replied: “I apologize for the delay. I have been having trouble getting in touch with my client. I will try a different avenue.”

Finally, on May 31, 2024, at 2:59 PM, Bryce Koon followed up once more: “Counsel, It has been quite some time, so I thought I would follow up on this one again. Please advise when we may expect your client’s discovery answers in this regard.” Each message in this sequence contains the standard confidentiality disclaimer typical of the sending firm.

In summary, the record shows a back-and-forth over several months (January through May 2024) concerning the timing of discovery responses in Debra Marshall’s case against Jasmine Reed, with parallel reference to a related property damage claim involving Edie Renick and a motion to consolidate that claim with the Debra Marshall case. The exchanges reflect multiple extensions requested and granted, ongoing difficulties contacting the client, and repeated follow-ups from The Whaley Law Firm seeking production of discovery responses.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022
Client: Debra Marshall

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Spoke to Robert Grant (obo client). Explained the we have been waiting for some responses to our discovery and they have essentially been avoiding us. Explained that I am going to file a Motion to Compel and hope to have a demand ready to go at the same time. I told him I would call him back in the next week or so when I have an update for him. He understood. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Bryce
__Date & Time__: October 10 2024
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on October 10, 2024, in Debra Marshall's motor vehicle accident matter (Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022). Bryce spoke with Robert Grant on behalf of Debra Marshall and explained that we have been waiting for responses to our discovery and that the other side has essentially been avoiding us. Bryce advised that a Motion to Compel would be filed and that a demand would be ready to go at the same time. Bryce also said that he would call Grant back in the next week or so when there is an update, and Grant understood.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. This matter concerns Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed in the Barren Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-00659. The correspondence below relates to the Debra Marshall motor vehicle accident matter (MVA 12/3/2022) and was sent by Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, with recipients and recipients’ details as shown in the header.

On October 10, 2024, at 03:48:55 GMT-04:00, Bryce Koon, Esq., wrote to counsel at Hensley & Ross, with Sarena Tuttle and Debra Marshall MVA 12/3/2022’s Filevine project email address copied on the message. In that note, he apologized for the inconvenience and informed counsel that the motion hour date would be moved to November 4, 2024, at 9:00 a.m. He provided the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The message included a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain privileged information, and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, not reveal or forward the information, and that no privilege waiver should be inferred. A similar disclaimer appeared at the end of the email.

Earlier that same day, at approximately 1:44 PM (noted as 1:44?PM in the record), Bryce Koon wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, Please see the attached Motion to Compel filed today. As you can see, this is set for motion hour on Monday, October 21, 2024. Should your office provide us with discovery responses prior to this date, we will remand our motion.” He also advised that Plaintiff’s Confidential Settlement Demand was attached and that a Dropbox link to related documents was provided: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/sc5yapd7wxz1zqjpvrlot/ABJjIzaAnDXFHO1REH3gx94?rlkey=9tr5vm3a6gtv6h94fdv4egkev&st=d1j39d92&dl=0. The message included the same closing courtesy and the Whaley Law Firm signature block, followed by a second, identical attorney-client privilege disclaimer. The signature block listed W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the same phone and fax numbers as above.

In summary, the case file for Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed involved two key November/October 2024 developments communicated by Bryce Koon: (1) a motion hour rescheduled to November 4, 2024 at 9:00 a.m., and (2) a Motion to Compel filed on October 10, 2024, which was set for motion hour on October 21, 2024, with a request for discovery responses to be provided prior to that date to remand the motion, along with Plaintiff’s Confidential Settlement Demand and a Dropbox link to related documents. The communications consistently carried standard confidentiality notices regarding privileged information and instruction not to forward the content if received in error.

On October 10, 2024, at 1:44 PM Eastern, the Kentucky Court of Justice eFiling system generated a notice for the case MARSHALL, DEBRA versus REED, JASMINE, Case No. 23-CI-00659, in the BARREN (CIRCUIT) Court. The filing was submitted by the eFiler, Aaron Gregory Whaley, an attorney for the plaintiff Debra Marshall. The envelope number associated with this filing is 9011568, and the notice relates to the captioned matter: MARSHALL, DEBRA vs. REED, JASMINE.

The following documents were included in this eFiling: a Motion to Compel, an Exhibit, and a Tendered Document labeled “Proposed / Tendered Order.” The notice indicates these items were delivered under envelope number 9011568 and provides additional details through the eFiling dashboard links. The From address for the notice was noreply@kycourts.net, and the case can be viewed or its documents retrieved via the links provided in the notice.

The electronic notice was sent to the following recipients: Whaley, Aaron Gregory (agwhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com) and Patrick A. Ross (hrh@scrtc.com). The To field in the header also lists agwhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and Bryce@WhaleyLawFirm.com, while the CC field is empty. The notice notes that this was automatically generated by the Kentucky Court of Justice eFiling system and advises not to reply to the email. For reference, the notice includes links to view details and documents (https://kcoj.kycourts.net/efiling/Dashboard/Receipt?caseid=9011568), to view the documents themselves (https://kcoj.kycourts.net/eFilingRetrieval/Home/Package?id=E28C2718-EAA6-42A5-9F47-E7F91018F206), and to file subsequent case matters (https://kcoj.kycourts.net/efiling/Filing/?parentId=9011568).

In addition, the message carries the Kentucky Court of Justice Confidentiality Notice, indicating the communication is intended for the addressee and may contain privileged or confidential information; if received in error, the recipient should contact the sender and delete the message and attachments. Case: Debra Marshall MVA 12/3/2022. Client: Debra Marshall. This matter concerns Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed in the Barren Circuit, case number 23-CI-00659. On October 10, 2024, at 3:48 p.m. in the Eastern time zone, Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to counsel at Hensley & Ross, with Sarena Tuttle and Debra Marshall MVA 12/3/2022 – Filevine Project Email Address copied on the message. He informed them that the motion hour date would be moved to November 4, 2024 at 9:00 a.m. The message included his standard professional signature, listing The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, along with the firm’s phone number (502) 365-5043 and fax number (502) 237-3207. It also carried a confidentiality disclaimer stating that the electronic communication is intended only for the named recipient and outlining protections for privileged information; recipients who receive the message in error were instructed to contact the firm and not use or forward the information.

Earlier on the same day, at approximately 1:44 p.m., Mr. Koon sent a separate email to counsel. In that message, he noted that the attached Motion to Compel had been filed that day and that it was set for motion hour on Monday, October 21, 2024. He stated that if the opposing office provided discovery responses prior to that date, they would remand the motion. He also transmitted Plaintiff’s Confidential Settlement Demand and provided a Dropbox link to related documents: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/sc5yapd7wxz1zqjpvrlot/ABJjIzaAnDXFHO1REH3gx94?rlkey=9tr5vm3a6gtv6h94fdv4egkev&st=d1j39d92&dl=0. He closed by inviting any questions and repeating his contact information and firm disclaimer. The signature block for this email was the same as in the later message, including The Whaley Law Firm’s address and phone and fax numbers. Both messages included the standard attorney-client confidentiality and privilege notices, indicating that the electronic communications were intended only for the named recipient and should not be used or shared if received in error.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Debra Marshall motor vehicle accident matter, Debra Marshall is the client in Debra Marshall v. Jasmine Reed, Barren Circuit Court case number 23-CI-00659, arising from a December 3, 2022 motor vehicle accident. The note documents a sequence of communications in October 2024 between counsel at The Whaley Law Firm and Hensley & Ross, with Debra Marshall copied on the Filevine project email address.

On October 14, 2024, at 09:46:29 a.m. Eastern Time, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to counsel at Hensley & Ross, to Sarena Tuttle, and to the Debra Marshall Filevine project email address. The subject line is not stated, but the body begins with “Good morning counsel,” and thanks them for their quick response. He states that attached is Plaintiff’s Notice of Remand. He signs as “W. Bryce Koon, Esq.” of The Whaley Law Firm, providing the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 237-3207. A standard attorney‑client confidentiality disclaimer follows, indicating the message is intended for the named recipient and advising what to do if received in error.

Earlier on October 14, 2024, this thread shows the history of communications from October 10, 2024. In the afternoon, Hensley & Ross responded to Bryce Koon’s prior messages with an apology. They stated that they had the signed interrogatories in the file but failed to file them and would do so in the morning. The message was from Pat at Hensley & Ross, Attorneys at Law, who provided the firm’s contact information: 207 E. Main St., P.O. Box 350, Horse Cave, KY 42749; phone (270) 786-2155 and fax (270) 786-2118. This message also included the standard confidentiality notice.

In a prior exchange on October 10, 2024 at 2:48 p.m., Bryce Koon replied to Hensley & Ross, stating, “My apologies counselor, I have been informed that the motion hour date will be moved to 11/04/24 at 9am.” His reply included the standard Whaley Law Firm signature block and contact information.

Earlier still on October 10, 2024 at 1:44 p.m., Bryce Koon sent another message to counsel. He attached the Motion to Compel, noting that it had been filed that day and that the motion would be set for motion hour on Monday, October 21, 2024. He advised that if the opposing side supplied discovery responses before that date, they would remand their motion. He also attached Plaintiff’s Confidential Settlement Demand and provided a Dropbox link to related documents: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/sc5yapd7wxz1zqjpvrlot/ABJjIzaAnDXFHO1REH3gx94?rlkey=9tr5vm3a6gtv6h94fdv4egkev&st=d1j39d92&dl=0. He closed with his contact information and the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

In each email, the sender included The Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality notice, and similarly, the Hensley & Ross messages included their confidentiality language. The communications collectively show that a Motion to Compel was filed on October 10, 2024, with a motion hour scheduled for October 21, 2024; Plaintiff’s Confidential Settlement Demand was provided; and the motion hour date was subsequently moved to November 4, 2024, at 9:00 a.m. The latest included document, Plaintiff’s Notice of Remand, was attached to the October 14, 2024 email from Bryce Koon.

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on December 3, 2022, with Debra Marshall regarding a motor vehicle accident. We have received both CMS and Rawlings PHI subrogation liens.

CMS billed $103,829.50 and has been paid $10,157.36. Rawlings billed $90,430.53 and has been paid $2,315.49. It appears the client's medical expenses total over $193,000.00; we have $173,260.39 listed, and this needs review.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022
Client: Debra Marshall

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client call Again - Advised nothing has changed from our discussion last week - BK has recvd the DC Resp to Disc Req - DC has our Demand Package - We anticipate some sort of answer by EOW - Response will dictate next move - If they make an offer on the Demand, we will move forward with Negotiations - If they do not respond to Demand, we will move forward with Litigation & begin scheduling Depositions - Either way we will reach out to discuss once determined - Client (Robert) expressed understanding - Client (Debra) in the background asked about Criminal Charges against Def - Advised she is welcome to contact the local PD in this regard, however, a PR was taken on the DOI & no criminal charges were pursued - Explained Criminal Charges are rare & unusual in a MVA situation - Clients expressed understanding 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: November 12 2024
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on November 12, 2024 with Debra Marshall regarding the motor vehicle accident case Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. The contact was made by Sarena. Debra Marshall called again; we advised that nothing has changed from our discussion last week. BK has recvd the DC Resp to Disc Req, and DC has our Demand Package. We anticipate some sort of answer by end of week, and the response will dictate the next move. If they make an offer on the Demand, we will move forward with negotiations; if they do not respond to the Demand, we will move forward with litigation and begin scheduling depositions. Either way we will reach out to discuss once determined. Client (Robert) expressed understanding. Debra, in the background, asked about criminal charges against the Defendant. I advised she is welcome to contact the local PD in this regard, however, a PR was taken on the DOI and no criminal charges were pursued. I explained criminal charges are rare and unusual in a motor vehicle accident situation. The clients expressed understanding.
episodes.author: Filevine Integration

episodes.natural_language:
Debra Marshall v Jasmine Reed is a matter in the Barren County Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-00659, arising from Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022. The structured note records communications between the two firms handling the case: Hensley & Ross (Pat Hensley, one of the attorneys) and The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager). The deposition in question concerns Jasmine Reed, with depositions being scheduled via Zoom.

On December 20, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Mr. Ross at Hensley & Ross stating, after a quick review of the file, that they were ready to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Reed and requesting dates when Mrs. Reed and Mr. Ross’s office would be available to participate via Zoom. The email emphasized the need to move forward with the deposition and closed with “Happy Holidays.” The message was sent by Sarena M. Tuttle, whose contact details at that time included The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (502) 357-9971, main line (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address).

In the ensuing communications on January 13, 2025, the Whaley firm followed up about scheduling. At 12:34 PM, Sarena Tuttle wrote Good afternoon Mr. Ross, noting that on December 20, 2024 they had reached out for dates to depose Mrs. Reed and that they were approaching 30 days without a response. She asked that dates for Mrs. Reed and his office to move forward with depositions be provided, and she stated they were open to discussing settlement if an offer was made in lieu of providing deposition dates. She reiterated their willingness to move forward and to avoid further delays.

Later that same day, at 1:40 PM, Sarena replied again, informing Mr. Ross that of the dates previously discussed, only February 20th works for them, and that they have a pretty open schedule for March if that would help. Pat Hensley then responded the same day at 2:33 PM with: “I will have to check with my client but How about February 17, 19, 20, or 21?” This inquiry was followed by a reply from Hensley & Ross at 3:02 PM: “Thanks, let me confirm with my client.”

At 2:21 PM on January 13, 2025, Sarena sent another brief reply: “Sounds good, thank you.” Finally, in the ongoing thread that same day, Pat Hensley noted that his client was available on Mondays due to a scheduling constraint related to Debra Marshall’s start in nursing school, and he proposed two Monday dates, March 3 or March 10, as possible deposition dates. This reflects Debra Marshall’s availability being limited to Mondays during her nursing school start.

For comfort and context, the record also includes the sending and receiving offices’ full contact details. Hensley & Ross is listed as Attor-neys at Law with a street address of 207 E. Main St., P.O. Box 350, Horse Cave, KY 42749, and contact numbers (270) 786-2155 and fax (270) 786-2118. The Whaley Law Firm is listed with the Louisville address of 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the contact numbers D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, with the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com and a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Overall, the deposition scheduling efforts centered on obtaining dates for Dr. Reed’s deposition via Zoom, with February 20 being workable for the Whaley firm, a potential open window in March, and the countervailing constraint that Debra Marshall would be available only on Mondays due to nursing school, prompting Pat Hensley to propose Monday dates in March (specifically March 3 or March 10). The exchange also touched on the possibility of settlement in lieu of depositions if a settlement offer could be made. The parties’ communications spanned December 20, 2024 through January 13, 2025, with repeated back-and-forth on preferred dates and ongoing confirmation efforts.
