Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. This narrative covers the communications regarding scheduling the deposition in Debra Marshall v Jasmine Reed, Barren County Circuit Court 23-CI-00659, with the deposition of Mrs. Reed to be conducted by Zoom.

Beginning with December 20, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm, through Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, informed Hensley & Ross that they were ready to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Reed. In that message, Sarena asked Pat Hensley of Hensley & Ross to provide dates when Mrs. Reed and their office were available for a Zoom deposition, and she wished to move forward with scheduling. She also noted the holiday season and signed the message with her firm’s contact details and her new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, indicating the address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with D: 502-357-9971 and O: 502-583-4022 ext 104.

On January 13, 2025, Hensley & Ross replied that their client was starting nursing school and was available only on Mondays, asking whether March 3 or March 10 would work. Sarena responded later that day, indicating that of the proposed dates, only February 20 would work for them, though they had a fairly open schedule for March if that could help. She again signed with The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and her new email address. Pat Hensley from Hensley & Ross then replied that he would have to check with his client, asking for confirmation.

Earlier that same day, Sarena sent another message confirming that the February 20 date would work for them and noting a relatively open March schedule if helpful. A subsequent message from Hensley & Ross suggested February 17, 19, 20, or 21 as possible dates, to which Sarena replied that she would need to confirm with her client. The exchange also included the CC of Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon in the December 20, 2024 thread and again reflected in the January 13, 2025 correspondence.

At 4:46 PM on January 13, 2025, Hensley & Ross wrote that their client was starting nursing school and was only available on Mondays, asking whether March 3 or March 10 would be workable. In response, on January 15, 2025 at 10:15 AM, Sarena acknowledged the dates, explaining that Mondays are difficult because of Jefferson County Motion Hour every Monday, but given the timeline, they should be able to make March 3, 2025 work. She proposed a start time of 1:00 PM EST and asked Pat to confirm if that time would be acceptable.

In summary, the parties were coordinating the deposition of Mrs. Reed in the Debra Marshall v Jasmine Reed matter, aiming to hold a Zoom deposition. The discussions spanned late December 2024 through mid-January 2025, with consideration given to the plaintiff’s counsel’s scheduling constraints (notably Mondays due to the client’s UNavailability and the attorney’s weekly schedule) and the goal of setting a deposition date for late February or early March 2025. The proposed resolution at the end of the chain was March 3, 2025, at 1:00 PM EST, pending confirmation. The communications consistently identified Debra Marshall as the client and Jasmine Reed as the deponent in the Barren County Circuit Court case 23-CI-00659, with the deposition to be conducted by Zoom.

Contact details present in the thread included:
- The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new email address). 
- The Opposing counsel, Hensley & Ross: 207 E. Main St., P.O. Box 350, Horse Cave, KY 42749; (270) 786-2155; fax (270) 786-2118. 
- The CC’d contacts in the December 20, 2024 thread included Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon.

Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022. Client: Debra Marshall. The matter is Debra Marshall v Jasmine Reed in the Barren County Circuit Court, docket 23-CI-00659, arising from a motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022. The following narrative summarizes the email exchanges between The Whaley Law Firm and Hensley & Ross from December 20, 2024 through January 15, 2025, regarding scheduling depositions of Jasmine Reed and Debra Marshall by Zoom, with times and availability discussed by the parties.

Beginning with December 20, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle (Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager) reached out to Pat Hensley of Hensley & Ross to set depositions for Mrs. Reed and to coordinate dates and times via Zoom. In a December 20, 2024 message, Sarena noted that in December 2024 they had previously contacted Hensley & Ross about deposition dates for Mrs. Reed and, after nearly 30 days without a response, urged the office to provide available dates for Mrs. Reed and their client to move forward, mentioning they were open to discussion of settlement if an offer was on the table. The emails from that date also included Sarena’s invitation to proceed with depositions and to communicate any questions, with CCs to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon. A follow-up note later that same day stated that they were ready to schedule Mrs. Reed’s deposition and requested dates that Mrs. Reed and the defense office were available via Zoom, closing with holiday wishes.

Moving into January 2025, the parties continued to negotiate dates. On January 13, 2025, Hensley & Ross proposed that their client could be available on February 17, 19, 20, or 21, noting that their client’s schedule needed checking. In response, Sarena acknowledged those options and stated that, of those dates, February 20 would work for them, while also noting that they had a fairly open March schedule if needed. Pat Hensley replied that he would need to confer with his client, and Sarena followed up with a message indicating that February 20 was acceptable for them and again highlighting a flexible March schedule if necessary. In that exchange, Hensley & Ross also explained that their client’s availability was constrained by a Monday-only schedule because she was starting nursing school and was unavailable on other days; Pat proposed March 3 or March 10 as alternatives.

On January 15, 2025, the thread progressed to more concrete timing. Sarena reaffirmed that February 20 remained the viable date, with the possibility of a March schedule if needed. Pat then asked whether the depositions could be conducted remotely and whether their client would be available. Sarena confirmed that a 1:30 p.m. start time would be suitable and indicated that Zoom would be an appropriate format. She added that Debra Marshall could be available that morning and asked whether they should begin Debra Marshall’s deposition at 10:00 a.m. EST.

Across these exchanges, the parties consistently discussed Zoom as the method for depositions, the availability of Jasmine Reed and Debra Marshall, and the impact of the defendants’ and plaintiffs’ schedules, including Monday-only constraints related to the defense client’s nursing studies and local court timing (notably Jefferson County Motion Hour on Mondays). The communications reflect ongoing efforts to finalize dates and times for the depositions of Jasmine Reed and Debra Marshall, with February 20 identified as workable for the Reed deposition and the potential for a March schedule if needed, alongside a proposed 1:30 p.m. time for one deposition and a 10:00 a.m. start for Debra Marshall on the same day.

In the Debra Marshall v Jasmine Reed matter (Barren County Circuit Court, 23-CI-00659), which stems from a motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022, Debra Marshall is represented by The Whaley Law Firm, and Jasmine Reed is represented by Hensley & Ross. The case has been set up to depose Jasmine Reed and Debra Marshall by Zoom, with the depositions to be conducted remotely.

On December 20, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm (contactable at Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com and at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext. 104), emailed Pat Ross of Hensley & Ross (to hrh@scrtc.com) requesting dates on which Jasmine Reed and the firm could depose Mrs. Reed via Zoom. She noted that the Whaley firm had previously reached out about deposition dates and had not received a response for nearly 30 days. She stated the office was ready to schedule and open to discussing settlement offers if the opposing side wished to make one. She asked that the offices provide dates for the depositions and indicated that if there were questions they could contact her to discuss further.

Over the following weeks, the parties exchanged several messages. Pat Ross suggested possible dates of February 17, 19, 20, or 21, noting his client’s availability constraints. Sarena responded that February 20 would work for them and that they had a fairly open schedule for March if that helped. The ongoing dialogue also revealed that Mrs. Reed’s counsel indicated Monday availability constraints due to the attorney’s schedule (the client was starting nursing school and would be available only on Mondays), leading to consideration of March 3 or March 10 as possible dates. Hensley & Ross reiterated their Monday-only constraint and proposed those March dates.

Throughout January 2025, Sarena and Pat continued to discuss preferred start times. At one point Sarena asked whether a 1:00 p.m. EST start would be acceptable, and later conversations anchored on a 1:30 p.m. start for the deposition of Jasmine Reed, with Zoom identified as the method. There were additional exchanges confirming that Jasmine Reed’s deposition would be conducted remotely and that Debra Marshall would also be deposed by Zoom. In a January 15, 2025 exchange, Hensley & Ross asked if Reed’s 1:30 p.m. start would work and whether the deposition could be conducted remotely, also inquiring about Debra Marshall’s availability.

On January 15, 2025, Sarena raised the possibility of a 1:00 p.m. EST start and noted the option of a 1:30 p.m. start, with Zoom as the preferred platform. By January 15, 2025 at 11:04 a.m., the parties appeared to converge on a plan: a 1:30 p.m. start for Jasmine Reed via Zoom, with Debra Marshall’s deposition also to be conducted via Zoom, and with Debra Marshall available that morning if a 10:00 a.m. EST start for her deposition was workable for the other side.

Finally, on January 17, 2025 at 1:16 p.m. (Eastern Time), Sarena Tuttle followed up to finalize the scheduling. The recap stated that, on March 3, 2025, Jasmine Reed would be deposed at 1:30 p.m. via Zoom, and that the Plaintiff’s deposition would also be conducted via Zoom at a time to be confirmed. She asked what start time would work best for beginning Debra Marshall’s deposition.

The latest scheduling communications also include contact details for Sarena Tuttle, who has a new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com), and reiterate the firm’s Louisville office at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. The Whaley Law Firm’s phone numbers are listed as D: 502-357-9971 and O: 502-583-4022 ext. 104, and the firm’s email is provided for further coordination.

In summary, the deposition schedule as of the latest communications is set for March 3, 2025, with Jasmine Reed’s deposition at 1:30 p.m. via Zoom, and Debra Marshall’s deposition to be conducted via Zoom in the morning, with an exact start time to be confirmed. The parties remain aligned on Zoom as the deposition method and are awaiting final confirmation of the Plaintiff’s start time.

In addition, she noted that they were looking to avoid further delays and invited discussion on settlement if appropriate.

On January 13, 2025, Tuttle responded to Hensley & Ross, noting that from the dates previously discussed, only February 20, 2025 worked for The Whaley Law Firm, with a March schedule that could be fairly open if needed. Hensley & Ross replied later that day, offering February 17, 19, 20, or 21 as alternatives and indicating they would need to check with their client. Tuttle then stated that of those dates, February 20 works for them, reiterating the possibility of a open March schedule if needed. Hensley & Ross followed up, saying they would confirm with their client. The firm then added that their client (Debra Marshall) is starting nursing school and is only available on Mondays, proposing March 3 or March 10 as options. 

On January 15, 2025, Tuttle indicated that a 1:30 p.m. start time was acceptable for Reed and suggested that Zoom would be a good format for this matter. She also asked whether Debra Marshall could be available that morning and whether they should start her deposition at 10:00 a.m. EST. Hensley & Ross asked for confirmation that the 1:30 p.m. time would work and whether the deposition would be conducted remotely, inquiring about the availability of their client on that schedule. Tuttle reaffirmed that 1:30 p.m. would work, that Zoom was suitable, and that Debra Marshall would be available that morning with an intended 10:00 a.m. start for her deposition, noting that the March 3, 2025 date would accommodate Reed’s 1:30 p.m. deposition via Zoom and that the plaintiff’s start time remained to be confirmed. 

On January 17, 2025, Hensley & Ross proposed finalizing the plaintiff’s start time at 10:30 a.m. EST, while keeping Jasmine Reed’s deposition for March 3, 2025 at 1:30 p.m. via Zoom. Sarena Tuttle then replied to confirm the March 3, 2025 schedule with Reed at 1:30 p.m. via Zoom and to request the plaintiff’s start time, noting that both depositions would be conducted via Zoom. The thread closes with Hensley & Ross confirming the 10:30 a.m. EST start for the plaintiff’s deposition and the 1:30 p.m. start for Reed on March 3, 2025.

Throughout these emails, the parties reference the following contact details and signatures:

- Hensley & Ross, Attorneys at Law
  207 E. Main St.
  P.O. Box 350
  Horse Cave, KY 42749
  (270) 786-2155
  fax (270) 786-2118
  The sender’s closing references Pat (P. Hensley) and the firm’s address were consistently included in the messages.

- The Whaley Law Firm, represented by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager
  712 Lyndon Lane
  Louisville, KY 40222
  D: (502) 357-9971
  O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
  E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
  Note in Tuttle’s signature: “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS”

- In the email chain, the subject line consistently references Debra Marshall v Jasmine Reed - Barren Co. Circuit Court 23-CI-00659, with Debra Marshall listed as the client for the case caption.

In summary, after an initial outreach in December 2024 seeking deposition dates and a lack of timely response, the parties engaged in a back-and-forth through January 2025 to align on dates. Debra Marshall’s deposition was ultimately scheduled for March 3, 2025 at 10:30 a.m. EST, with Jasmine Reed’s deposition set for March 3, 2025 at 1:30 p.m. via Zoom, both sessions to be conducted remotely. The proceedings were positioned as Zoom depositions, with ongoing coordination between The Whaley Law Firm and Hensley & Ross to confirm the plaintiff’s start time on that date.

On Friday, January 17, 2025, theKentuckiana Reporters Scheduling Department sent an email to sarena@whaleylawfirm.com (the To address for the Whaley Law Firm) with the subject line “Re: New submission from 20 Second Scheduler.” Dated 20:58:14 +0000, the message acknowledged that there was no problem and stated that the submission would be added to their calendar and that Zoom details would be emailed prior to the proceeding. The email was signed by Madison and came from the Scheduling Team at Kentuckiana Reporters, which included Kristina Rahm, McKenna Watson, and Madison Elam. The message provided contact information for the Scheduling Team: P: 502-589-2273; E: Schedule@kentuckianareporters.com; A: 730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202. It also contained a Cancellation Policy noting that a cancellation fee applies to all assignments canceled with less than 24 hours’ notice, and that interpreter requests canceled within 24 hours of the appointment time will be billed at the industry standard of a two-hour minimum rate.

Earlier that day, at 3:49 PM, an automated message from donotreply@kentuckianareporters.com (on behalf of donotreply@kentuckianareporters.com) was sent to the Scheduling Department with the subject “New submission from 20 Second Scheduler.” The message carried the following details from Sarena Tuttle, whose email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com: Additional Comments state, “Def Depo at 1:30p via Zoom or immediately Following Plaintiff - Plaintiff scheduled to start at 1030a - Not sure who DC is using for court reporter at this time.” The notice also referenced a file named 2025.01.17-Marshall-NTTD-Def-Jasmine-Reed-03.03.2025-130p-Zoom.pdf, indicating attached notice materials related to the deposition scheduling.

>>>>>>>> dates that Mrs. Reed and your office are available via Zoom. If you have

episodes.natural_language:
In the Debra Marshall v Jasmine Reed matter, Barren County Circuit Court case number 23-CI-00659 (the file also references Debra Marshall’s motor vehicle accident on December 3, 2022, labeled Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022), The Whaley Law Firm prepared and sent a Notice to Take Deposition of Jasmine Reed. The notice was filed via CourtNet and carried envelope number 9684744. The transmission came from Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct dial 502-357-9971 and main office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104. Her email address noted on the message was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (marked as the new email address). The recipient was Hensley & Ross, Attorneys at Law, at 207 E. Main St., P.O. Box 350, Horse Cave, KY 42749, with the firm’s phone number 270-786-2155 and fax 270-786-2118.

The scheduling of depositions progressed through a lengthy email chain beginning in December 2024. On December 20, 2024, Sarena Tuttle stated that, after a quick review of the file, the parties were ready to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Reed and asked for dates when Jasmine Reed and Hensley & Ross could participate via Zoom, inviting any questions and even offering settlement discussions if an offer was being considered to move the matter forward. In the subsequent exchanges on January 13, 2025, Sarena reminded that on December 20, 2024 she had reached out for deposition dates and noted that the matter was approaching 30 days without a response; she requested dates for depositions via Zoom and indicated openness to settlement discussions if appropriate. Pat Hensley of Hensley & Ross replied that he would need to check with his client and proposed dates of February 17, 19, 20, or 21. Sarena acknowledged, and Pat added that his client would be available Mondays, explaining that the defendant’s schedule was constrained by his client’s nursing school.

The conversation continued with further back-and-forth in mid-January 2025. On January 13, 2025, Sarena confirmed that the February dates would need to be weighed and indicated that the March dates might be workable. Pat responded that his client would be available on Mondays for scheduling, proposing March 3 or March 10 as possibilities. Sarena then suggested that 1:30 p.m. could work and asked whether a 10:00 a.m. start for Debra Marshall would be feasible, noting that Zoom would be used for the depositions. Pat asked whether the proceedings would be remote and whether Debra Marshall would be available. Sarena replied affirmatively to the remote format and the 1:30 p.m. time, and suggested starting Mrs. Marshall at 10:00 a.m. EST. The parties continued to discuss the plan, with the understanding that the March 3 date remained a viable option.

By January 17, 2025, the scheduling had crystallized further: the plan was for March 3, 2025, with Jasmine Reed’s deposition at 1:30 p.m. via Zoom, and the plaintiff’s deposition to be held via Zoom as well with a start time to be confirmed. At roughly the same time, Hensley & Ross suggested a start time of 10:30 a.m. for the plaintiff’s deposition, and Sarena indicated she would send the notice shortly. Later that day, Sarena confirmed the plan and issued the deposition notice: “Here is our Notice to Take Deposition of Jasmine Reed, filed via CourtNet Envelope 9684744 moments ago,” accompanied by the sender’s details and the reminder to use the new email address. The notice was sent to Hensley & Ross, with the expectation that the depositions would proceed by Zoom on March 3, 2025, Reed at 1:30 p.m. and the plaintiff at 10:30 a.m., both to be conducted remotely. The communications also recorded that the notice was filed via CourtNet and included the exchange history and the participants’ contact information, including Sarena’s updated email address.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022
Client: Debra Marshall

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd FG Note about Client looking for update - Already s/w Anna per Client instructions
Client call again for update on 02.21
Sent Anna Text w/Update for Client - Advised no movement until 30 days post Deposition (03.03.2025) 

Good morning Anna,
We have received another call from Debra on Friday. Please let her know that there will be no additional updates until approximately 30 days after her deposition. Once the depositions are complete, both attorneys will review the information and decide if additional discovery is required. If so, Discovery will resume and will take an additional 60 days. If not, they will discuss the possibility of settlement again. It is possible that they may decide to schedule a mediation, however, none of this will happen prior to April 3, 2025. If she has any specific questions, she is welcome to give us a call to discuss them in further detail. Please let her know, she needs to be contact Bryce or myself, as she keeps leaving voicemails for Justin, who is no longer her case manager. I can be reached at Ext 104 and Bryce can be reached at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: February 24 2025
episodes.natural_language:

The client contact log shows that the team received an FG note indicating Debra was seeking an update, and that communications have already been routed to Anna per the client’s instructions. Debra made another call for an update on February 21, 2025. A text with an update was sent to Anna, advising no movement until 30 days after her deposition, which is scheduled for March 3, 2025.

The text message to Anna, authored by Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm, states: “Good morning Anna, We have received another call from Debra on Friday. Please let her know that there will be no additional updates until approximately 30 days after her deposition. Once the depositions are complete, both attorneys will review the information and decide if additional discovery is required. If so, Discovery will resume and will take an additional 60 days. If not, they will discuss the possibility of settlement again. It is possible that they may decide to schedule a mediation, however, none of this will happen prior to April 3, 2025. If she has any specific questions, she is welcome to give us a call to discuss them in further detail. episodes.original_body:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022
Client: Debra Marshall

Good morning Anna,
 We have received another call from Debra on Friday. Please let her know that there will be no additional updates until approximately 30 days after her deposition. Once the depositions are complete, both attorneys will review the information and decide if additional discovery is required. If so, Discovery will resume and will take an additional 60 days. If not, they will discuss the possibility of settlement again. It is possible that they may decide to schedule a mediation, however, none of this will happen prior to April 3, 2025. If she has any specific questions, she is welcome to give us a call to discuss them in further detail. Please let her know, she needs to be contact Bryce or myself, as she keeps leaving voicemails for Justin, who is no longer her case manager. I can be reached at Ext 104 and Bryce can be reached at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm
episodes.natural_language:
Case Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022 involves client Debra Marshall. On Friday we received another call from Debra. Sarena from The Whaley Law Firm asked Anna to inform Debra that there will be no additional updates until approximately 30 days after her deposition.

After the depositions are complete, both attorneys will review the information and decide whether additional discovery is required. If discovery is necessary, it will resume and take an additional 60 days. If not, they will discuss the possibility of settlement again. It is possible that they may decide to schedule a mediation; however, none of this will happen prior to April 3, 2025. If Debra has any specific questions, she is welcome to call to discuss them in further detail.

Please let her know that she needs to contact Bryce or me, as she has been leaving voicemails for Justin, who is no longer her case manager. I can be reached at Ext 104 and Bryce at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

The conversation focused on coordinating the next steps in a legal case involving clients Deborah Marshall and Jasmine Reed. The outcome included an agreement to share necessary documents and schedule mediation.
Recap
Aaron Whaley confirmed that they are following up on a legal case involving clients Deborah Marshall and Jasmine Reed, previously handled by Bryce, who has since left the firm.
Ross confirmed that they have taken the deposition of Jasmine Reed and acknowledged the need for medical records to evaluate the case further.
Ross suggested that mediation is the next step, as it is typically recommended by Alexander, and expressed a desire to resolve the case promptly after returning from vacation.
Aaron Whaley agreed to send all relevant records and bills to Ross to facilitate the review and mediation scheduling.
Tasks
Aaron Whaley will send all relevant records and bills to Ross by the end of the week or sometime next week to assist in case evaluation and mediation scheduling.

Ross confirmed that Jasmine Reed’s deposition has been taken and acknowledged the need for medical records to evaluate the case further. Ross suggested that mediation is the next step, as it is typically recommended by Alexander, and expressed a desire to resolve the case promptly after returning from vacation. Aaron Whaley agreed to send all relevant records and bills to Ross to facilitate the review and mediation scheduling.

As a concrete next step, Aaron Whaley will send all relevant records and bills to Ross by the end of the week or sometime next week to assist in case evaluation and the scheduling of mediation.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022
Client: Debra Marshall

The conversation provided an update on the legal case involving Mr. Marshall, detailing the progress made and the next steps towards mediation.

Recap

* Aaron Whaley provided an update on Mr. Marshall's case, confirming that all initial discovery has been completed and that they will send the defense attorney all medical records and bills by the end of the week or next week.
* Once the defense attorney reviews the documents, they will schedule a mediation date to attempt to settle the case.
* Aaron explained the challenges in estimating a monetary value for the case due to disputes over liability and the nature of the injuries, indicating that while there is a risk of receiving nothing, there is also a significant incentive for the opposing party to negotiate due to high medical bills.

Tasks

* Aaron Whaley will send all medical records and bills to the defense attorney by the end of the week or next week.
* Aaron will follow up to schedule a mediation date once the defense attorney has reviewed the documents.
episodes.natural_language:
Case Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022 involves client Debra Marshall. The latest conversation provided an update on Mr. Marshall’s legal case, detailing progress toward mediation and the next steps.

According to the update from Aaron Whaley, all initial discovery has been completed, and the team will send the defense attorney all medical records and bills by the end of the week or next week. Once the defense attorney reviews the documents, they will schedule a mediation date in an effort to settle the case. Aaron explained that estimating a monetary value for the case is challenging due to disputes over liability and the nature of the injuries. There is a risk of receiving nothing, but there is also a significant incentive for the opposing party to negotiate because of high medical bills.

The tasks outlined are: Aaron Whaley will send all medical records and bills to the defense attorney by the end of the week or next week, and Aaron will follow up to schedule a mediation date once the defense attorney has reviewed the documents.
episodes.author: Aaron

about.relevance: attorney providing update and handling tasks
recipient of medical records and scheduler of mediation

episodes.original_body:
Case: Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022
Client: Debra Marshall

The conversation focused on determining whether to file a motion for a trial date or pursue mediation regarding a legal matter. The outcome is that a motion will be filed if no resolution is reached by Friday.
Recap
Aaron Wy discussed with Ann Dattillo the options of filing a motion for a trial date or pursuing mediation, indicating that if no decision is made by Friday, they will file the motion for trial to secure a firm date.
Ann inquired about the necessity of Debbie's presence at the trial, to which Aaron clarified that while she would likely need to be there, he is not keen on going to trial due to her emotional instability.
They agreed that if mediation occurs, it would likely be conducted over the phone or via Zoom, making it more convenient for Ann.
Tasks
Aaron Wy will file a motion for a trial date if no resolution is reached by Friday.
Ann Dattillo is responsible for arranging travel for Debbie if the trial proceeds.
episodes.natural_language:
Case Debra-Marshall-MVA-12-3-2022 involves Debra Marshall and centers on whether to file a motion for a trial date or pursue mediation in her motor vehicle accident matter. The discussion concluded that a motion for a trial date will be filed if no resolution is reached by Friday.

In a planning conversation, attorney Aaron Wy spoke with Ann Dattillo about two options: filing a motion for a trial date or pursuing mediation. They agreed that if no decision is made by Friday, they will file the motion for a trial to secure a firm date.

Ann inquired about whether Debra (Debbie) would need to be present at the trial. Aaron clarified that while she would likely need to be there, he is not keen on going to trial due to her emotional instability.

They also agreed that if mediation occurs, it would likely be conducted over the phone or via Zoom, which would be more convenient for Ann.

Action items: Aaron Wy will file a motion for a trial date if no resolution is reached by Friday. Ann Dattillo will arrange travel for Debra if the trial proceeds.
episodes.author: Aaron

about.relevance: attorney planning to file motion for trial date
